Cuz character arcs and plotting are things I do.

title: It’s not your story
body:
A friend of mine was pleased with the ending Tyrion got, since he was his favorite character. He told me that it’s silly to see the backlash this show is getting over simple things, and says, “the writers said what they wanted to say. It is their story, not ours.” And that made me think real hard.

As an English Literature student, I love to read and sometimes write fiction. Anyone of you who are fanfic writers will know, that the moment you share your creation with the public, it’s no longer your story anymore. It’s yours and ours. You spend your valuable time and put hard work in writing a piece of content, and we spend our time reading your material. We agree upon it, we disagree upon it, we discuss, we theorize, we do all sorts of things as fans. For GOT fans, it’s even more. You’re literally paying HBO and the writers for their content. You invest your time and emotion behind the story and the characters. I don’t understand why some parts of the fandom, whether they’re casual or avid fans, try to shun us for voicing out our opinions about the story. As much as I agree with the fact that yes, it is their story, you can’t expect your viewers to not have an opinion about your content. You can’t expect them to not voice out their opinions loudly. You can’t expect them to simply sit on their sofas, watch your show, and say nothing about it. We’re not some fools who stare at a screen while drooling on the floor. We’re intelligent beings. We understand narration, character arc, lore, soundtrack, the littlest things. If you’re going to murder your own story and expect fans to stay quiet about it, the same fans you reach out to, people who are paying money to watch your content, the people who have invested 10 years of their time and energy behind this, then you’re a bunch of idiots. You want us to speak about it because it gives you exposure. You wouldn’t say “It’s not your story” if the people liked what you’re showing. But when you know you’re in the shit, and you pull the “It’s not your story” card it makes you look arrogant, and anyone who defends this idea, is a fool. It is your story, but it’s ours as well, and you can’t fight that. And the next time you consider writing a story and undermine your audience, your cast, and your crew, then you better stick those scripts up your ass, because it ain’t worth it.

summary:
Writers: Here is the set of rules my fictional universe operates in.
Devoted fan: Okay, based on these rules, I think the story...
body:
Writers: Here is the set of rules my fictional universe operates in.

Devoted fan: Okay, based on these rules, I think the story might end this way.

Writers: … How dare you think critically about this story! What, you think you’re smarter than me?

Devoted fan: What? No.

Writers shoot the rules in the face

Writers: Why does no one like this story?

summary: Emilia Clarke did not suffer through all that pain to get this ending in GoT...
body:
Emilia Clarke did not suffer through all that pain to get this ending in GoT…

Can you believe that Emilia Clarke survived 2 aneurysms, went through severe depression because of it and her GoT family kept her going, Daenerys kept her going, because she saw herself in Dany, all the pain they both overcame. She connected with Daenerys on a whole new lever. ALL of that, the long journey she’s had with Dany JUST for D&D to completely destroy her character in the final season by turning her mad in the last 3 episodes! 8 YEAR of character development for them to then just dispose of her like trash! After getting the script Emilia Clarke was crying and called her mother and brother to ask if they “think that Daenerys is a good person”. I can’t even begin to explain how much this breaks my fucking heart…I am not just heartbroken for Dany who l love more than anyone on the show, but even more so for Emilia. I have an ocean of love for both Emilia and Daenerys, which is why this hurts so much.. I almost never cry but l cried so much after the finale and then again reading how much it broke both Emilia and Kit’s heart when they read the final script! I’m honestly disgusted by D&D and how they’ve handled these last 3 episodes. But I’m not going to let them ruin Daenerys for me, I don’t accept this ending as canon.

I will forever remember her as the girl with silver hair that was told she’s nothing by her brother, was abused and then rose out of the ashes with 3 dragons, stronger than ever and continuously defied all odds! Remember her as the strong, kind, caring, fierce and badass leader that she is! “Daenerys of the House Targaryen, the First of Her Name, The Unburnt, Queen of the Andals, the Rhoynar and the First Men, Queen of Meereen, Khaleesi of the Great Grass Sea, Protector of the Realm, Lady Regent of the Seven Kingdoms, Breaker of Chains and Mother of Dragons!“

Finally l want to thank Emilia Clarke especially and the whole cast with all of my heart for doing such an incredible job all of these years portraing their characters best they could! Despite the shitty script they were given at the end they all did an incredible job! 👏🏼👏🏼👏🏼

tags: like the screen faded to black and it's like -- lol welcome to the new cycle of being duped by propaganda!
summary: Aright, high point of that episode, and maybe of the season was Tyrion’s speech to Jon in the cell about the propaganda of...
body:
Aright, high point of that episode, and maybe of the season was Tyrion’s speech to Jon in the cell about the propaganda of tyranny – other than that :sigh: what an unimaginative ending. Playing off the idea that progress has to move on this trodden path of reformist change. It’s a fantasy show – this is the place where the imaginative process can flourish. But everyone is back where they started, more or less, just with the vague promise of a monarch chosen by…..hereditary house lords.

And it’s telling that we never see the people of King’s Landing again after they’ve served their purpose of dying. The masses are there as a sacrifice to provide a reason to change, but there’s no conception of how they can be a creative force for change, except for Sam, bless him. I know that narratively there’s a duty to serve the characters in ending their arcs, but the fact that all of their arcs were settled into the rhythms and habits of the old world, once again completely removed from the working people of Westeros was just kind of…why? Why are those the limits?

The best part of this story was the frog-in-the-cauldron experiment that it put the viewers through - how much tyrannical imperialism will you cheer on if it’s couched in palatable propaganda? But the imagination of the what a world could be beyond that fell victim to the centrist reformist’s idea of change, and brings us back to a system in which the people are dependent on the perceived benevolence of their overlords. Where grand lords make decisions based on what they perceive as morally correct. Which, based on Daenerys’s arc, casts a really dark pallor over the entire thing.

We get the feeling that the world is in good hands at the end, but as Tyrion says at the kingsmoot (which it was, really), the thing that drives people are stories. The story being told to us at the end is that all is well and in kind and benevolent hands. But that’s the story we were told about the Dragon Queen until we received another perspective.

And again, the perspective missing from the end of this is the perspective of the citizens, the people, the peasantry. They still don’t have a choice, their lives are still at the behest of people sat around a table high above their heads. The value of the various thrones are still based on the extracted value of their labour according to their liege lords. Those liege lords are still beholden to no one but others of their class. 

And that’s terrifying based on what we just learned over the course of 8 seasons. In reality, the wheel is still turning.

The best part of this story was the frog-in-the-cauldron experiment that it put the viewers through - how much tyrannical imperialism will you cheer on if it’s couched in palatable propaganda? But the imagination of the what a world could be beyond that fell victim to the centrist reformist’s idea of change, and brings us back to a system in which the people are dependent on the perceived benevolence of their overlords. Where grand lords make decisions based on what they perceive as morally correct. Which, based on Daenerys’s arc, casts a really dark pallor over the entire thing.

We get the feeling that the world is in good hands at the end, but as Tyrion says at the kingsmoot (which it was, really), the thing that drives people are stories. The story being told to us at the end is that all is well and in kind and benevolent hands. But that’s the story we were told about the Dragon Queen until we received another perspective.

And again, the perspective missing from the end of this is the perspective of the citizens, the people, the peasantry. They still don’t have a choice, their lives are still at the behest of people sat around a table high above their heads. The value of the various thrones are still based on the extracted value of their labour according to their liege lords. Those liege lords are still beholden to no one but others of their class. 

And that’s terrifying based on what we just learned over the course of 8 seasons. In reality, the wheel is still turning.
